questions.text: A 45-year-old man is being evaluated for fracture union 8 weeks after sustaining a tibial shaft fracture. Which of the following is NOT a clinical sign of fracture union?

choices.text: Ability to bear weights
Presence of tenderness at the fracture site
Absence of free movement between the fractured fragments
Visible callus bridging the fractured site on X-ray

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Presence of tenderness at the fracture site

Explanation:
Presence of tenderness at the fracture site is not a sign of fracture union. In fact, absence of tenderness at the fracture site is one of the clinical signs of fracture union.

Signs of Fracture Union

Clinical Signs

Radiological Signs
  • Absence of free movement between the fractured fragments (Option C)
  • Absence of tenderness at the fracture site
  • No pain/tenderness on palpation/examination
  • Ability to bear weight (Option A)
  • Visible callus bridging the fractured site and connecting the fractured fragments (Option D)
  • Continuity of bone trabeculae across the fracture - Bridging callus

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a motorcycle accident. Upon examination, he has severe pelvic pain and is unable to bear weight. Radiographic imaging reveals a complete disruption of the posterior pelvic arch, with associated sacral fractures and displacement. Based on the findings, which type of pelvic fracture classification does this injury belong to?

choices.text: Type A
Type B
Type C
Type D

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Type C

 

Explanation:

Type C indicates a complete disruption of the posterior pelvic arch, often associated with severe instability. Given the scenario's description of a complete disruption with sacral fractures, this is the correct classification.

 

Tiles Classification of Pelvic Fractures

Type

Stability

Subtype

A

Stable (posterior arch intact)

(Option A)

A1: Avulsion injury

A2: Iliac-wing or anterior-arch fracture due to a direct blow

A3: Transverse sacrococcygeal fracture

B

Partially stable (incomplete disruption of the posterior arch)

(Option B)

B1: Open-book injury (external rotation)

B2: Lateral-compression injury (internal rotation)

  • B2-1: Ipsilateral anterior and posterior injuries
  • B2-2: Contralateral (bucket-handle) injuries

B3: Bilateral

C

Unstable

(complete disruption of the posterior arch)

C1: Unilateral

  • C1-1: Iliac fracture
  • C1-2: Sacroiliac fracture-dislocation
  • C1-3: Sacral fracture

C2: Bilateral, with one side type B, one side type C

C3: Bilateral


 

Type D (Option D): There is no Type D in the Tile classification of pelvic fractures. This option is irrelevant to the scenario.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with progressive knee pain, swelling, reduced range of motion, and occasional mechanical locking. An X-ray of the knee is given below. MRI confirms the presence of lobular cartilage nodules with areas of calcification. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Observation and conservative management
Arthroscopic synovectomy and loose body removal
Total knee replacement
Physical therapy only

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Arthroscopic synovectomy and loose body removal

 

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with knee pain, swelling, reduced range of motion, and mechanical locking, which are hallmark features of synovial chondromatosis.
  • The X-ray showing multiple calcified loose bodies and the MRI confirming lobular cartilage nodules with areas of calcification further support this diagnosis.
  • Given the severe symptoms (pain, limited motion, and locking) and imaging findings of calcified loose bodies, arthroscopic synovectomy and removal of the loose bodies is the recommended treatment. This approach addresses both symptom relief and prevents further joint damage.

Imaging

  • Radiographs: Standard anteroposterior (AP) and lateral views of the affected joint are recommended. Findings vary by disease stage and may show stippled calcification.

Fig. Plain X-ray of chondromatosis of elbow

Fig. Plain X-ray of chondromatosis of hip joint

  • MRI: Initially, cartilage nodules are visible only on MRI, appearing lobular. In later stages, there is a signal drop-out indicating calcification.

Fig. MRI of synovial chondromatosis of the knee

Histology

  • Displays discrete hyaline cartilage nodules at various stages of calcification and ossification, with mild atypia, binucleate cells, and occasional mitoses.

Fig. Histology of chondromatosis

Treatment:

  • Nonoperative: Observation is recommended for mild symptoms that do not affect range of motion.
  • Operative: Open or arthroscopic synovectomy and loose body resection are indicated for severe symptoms impacting range of motion.
  • Outcomes: Treatment is symptomatic and may help prevent degenerative changes in the joint.

 

Observation and conservative management (Option A) is reserved for mild cases not affecting joint function.

 

Total knee replacement (Option C) is not typically indicated unless severe degenerative changes are present, which is not mentioned in this case.

 

Physical therapy only (Option D) alone would not resolve the mechanical issues caused by the loose bodies.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with progressive knee pain and swelling over the past few months. He reports occasional mechanical locking during movement and a reduced range of motion. Physical examination reveals mild joint swelling, crepitus, and limited knee flexion. An X-ray shows multiple calcified loose bodies within the joint space but no apparent synovial involvement. Based on the Milgram Classification, which stage does this patient’s condition most likely fall into?

choices.text: Early stage (Class I)
Intermediate stage (Class II)
Final stage (Class III)
None of the above

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Final stage (Class III)

 

Explanation:

  • Presenting with progressive knee pain, swelling, reduced range of motion, and mechanical locking, with X-ray showing multiple calcified loose bodies in the joint space are features consistent with synovial chondromatosis, a condition where loose chondroid bodies form in the joint.
  • The absence of active synovial involvement on imaging, combined with the presence of calcified loose bodies, classifies this case as Class III (Final stage) of Milgram's classification.

 

Synovial Chondromatosis

  • Synovial chondromatosis is a benign condition where the synovial membrane of joints forms multiple loose chondroid bodies, leading to joint pain, swelling, and decreased range of motion.
  • Sites:
    • Knee: Most common
    • Shoulder
    • Hip
    • Elbow
  • Presents with joint pain as the chief complaint, often accompanied by swelling, reduced range of motion, and occasionally crepitus and mechanical locking during movement.
  • Milgram Classification
    • Early stage (Class I) - Synovial symptoms without any loose bodies visible on X-Rays. (Option A)
    • Intermediate stage (Class II) - Reunites both clinical symptoms and images of calcified loose bodies within the synovial membrane. (Option B)
    • Final stage (Class III) - Calcified loose bodies without any synovial involvement

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to the clinic after a routine physical examination reveals shoulder abnormalities like in the given image. The child is otherwise healthy and shows no significant discomfort. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Sprengel’s Deformity
Klippel–Feil Syndrome
Madelung's Deformity
Cleidocranial Dysostosis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Cleidocranial Dysostosis

 

Explanation:

Cleidocranial Dysostosis is characterized by the partial or complete absence of the clavicles, often leading to shoulder abnormalities discovered incidentally. X-ray findings confirm the diagnosis, and while treatment is usually unnecessary, surgery may be considered if pain occurs.

Cleidocranial Dysostosis

  • Rare condition with partial or complete absence of the clavicles.
  • Exact cause unknown, possibly due to disruption of membranous bone development during early embryonic life.

Types:

  • Pseudarthritic gap between ends of bones
  • Partial defect, usually at the acromial end
  • Complete absence of clavicle

Associated Muscle Variations:

  • Trapezius may be absent
  • Pectoralis major may be underdeveloped
  • Other congenital malformations may occur

Clinical Features:

  • Shoulder abnormalities discovered accidentally
  • Mimics un-united fracture or complete absence of the clavicle
  • Shoulders can be approximated
  • X-rays of both clavicles are essential for diagnosis.

Treatment:

  • No treatment usually required
  • Surgery (removal of part of the clavicle) if pain occurs
  • No significant disability or discomfort

Sprengel’s Deformity (Option A): This condition is characterized by an elevated scapula due to improper descent during embryonic development, not a clavicular abnormality. The deformity is noticeable at birth, with limited shoulder movement, which is not consistent with this scenario.

 

Klippel–Feil Syndrome (Option B): This syndrome involves cervical vertebrae abnormalities and results in a short, stiff neck with low hairline and webbing, leading to significant neck movement limitations. It does not relate to clavicle absence or shoulder positioning.

 

Madelung's Deformity (Option C): This deformity affects the distal radial epiphysis and is unrelated to the clavicles or shoulder positioning. It presents with forearm deformities rather than shoulder abnormalities and does not fit the clinical findings in this case.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident where his forehead struck the steering wheel. He complains of neck pain but no neurological deficits. Imaging reveals a fracture of the pars interarticularis of C2 with anterior displacement of the vertebra. There is 4 mm of subluxation at the C2/3 level. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Rigid cervical collar
Halo fixation for 6 to 12 weeks
Immediate surgical intervention
Conservative management with analgesics and observation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Halo fixation for 6 to 12 weeks

 

Explanation:

Halo fixation for 6 to 12 weeks is the correct treatment for Type 2 fractures of Levin and Edward Classification with subluxation greater than 3 mm but less than 5 mm. It provides sufficient immobilization for the fracture to heal.

C2 Traumatic Spondylolisthesis (Hangman’s Fracture)

  • Cause: Traditionally from judicial hanging; now more commonly due to hyperextension injuries (e.g., force to the forehead, Forsyth mechanism).
  • Injury: Results in anterior translation at C2, leading to pars fractures and possible C2/3 disc disruption.
  • Neurological Injury: Uncommon, as the fractures can expand the spinal canal.
  • Stability Assessment: Depends on C2/3 disc status and facet integrity.

Levine & Edward Classification

Treatment

Type 1: Less than 3 mm subluxation, stable

Rigid cervical collar (Option A)

Type 2: Greater than 4 mm subluxation, unstable

-Less than 5 mm - Reduction in axial traction and halo fixation for 6 to 12 weeks

-Greater than 5 mm - Require surgery (Option C)

Type 2a: Unstable with flexion injury and angular deformity

Halo fixation

Type 3: Unstable with facet and anterior longitudinal ligament disruption

Require surgery (Option C)

 

Conservative management with analgesics and observation (Option D): This approach would not be appropriate for an unstable fracture like Type 2, as it requires immobilization to ensure proper healing and to prevent further displacement.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a high-impact motorcycle accident. He presents with significant swelling and bruising in the lower abdomen and thighs. During the examination, he exhibits tenderness upon palpation of the abdomen. Pelvic compression test is positive. The patient is unable to void, and the bladder is not palpable. What is the most appropriate initial management step for this patient?

choices.text: Immediate surgery for internal fixation
Apply pelvic binders and initiate resuscitation
Order a CT scan of the pelvis
Initiate strict bed rest and monitor vital signs

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Apply pelvic binders and initiate resuscitation

 

Explanation:

  • The patient is suspected to have pelvic fractures due to significant swelling and bruising in the lower abdomen and thighs, tenderness indicating possible intraperitoneal bleeding, a positive pelvic compression test and an inability to void suggesting a potential bladder rupture.
  • Applying pelvic binders helps stabilize the pelvis and reduce hemorrhage while initiating resuscitation is critical for managing potential hemorrhagic shock.

Clinical Features of Pelvic Fractures

  • Swelling and Bruising: Lower abdomen, thighs, perineum, scrotum, or vulva.
  • Abdominal Tenderness: Indicates intraperitoneal bleeding.
  • Extraperitoneal Bladder Rupture: Suspect if unable to void or palpate bladder; may lead to significant hemorrhage.
  • Neurological Damage: Assess for lumbosacral plexus injury, especially in unconscious patients

Treatment of Pelvic Ring Fractures:

  1. Initial Management:
    • Follow ATLS protocol (Advanced Trauma Life Support).
    • Immediate resuscitation and management of hemorrhagic shock using blood products.
  2. Pelvic Binders:
    • Applied at the level of the greater trochanters, not the iliac crest.
    • Temporarily stabilizes the pelvis and reduces pelvic volume, limiting blood loss.
    • Should not be left on for more than 24 hours due to the risk of pressure sores.
    • May need to be loosened if over-reduced (excessive internal rotation of the hemipelvis).
    • Reapplication is possible after checking pressure areas.
  3. Management of Hemorrhage:
    • If the patient remains hemodynamically unstable despite a binder and resuscitation:
      • Exclude other sources of bleeding (chest, abdomen, external).
      • Two main options:
        1. Angiography and Embolization: Targets arterial bleeding, controls vessels like the internal iliac and superior gluteal arteries. Risks include muscle necrosis (gluteals).
        2. Pre-peritoneal Packing: Requires rapid application of an external fixator and abdominal packing (Stoppa approach). May be followed by angiography if needed.
  4. Conservative Management:
    • Used for stable fractures such as avulsion fractures and LC I fractures.
    • Early mobilization and partial weight-bearing are encouraged to avoid complications (e.g., VTE, chest infections).
  5. Operative Fixation:
    • Converts unstable fractures to stable configurations using open reduction, internal fixation (plates, screws), or percutaneous iliosacral screws.
    • Sacral fractures and sacroiliac dislocations may require closed or open reduction.

Immediate surgery for internal fixation (Option A): Immediate surgery for internal fixation is not the first step in trauma management. Stabilization and resuscitation are prioritized.

 

Order a CT scan of the pelvis (Option C): While imaging may be necessary, the immediate management should focus on stabilization and addressing hemodynamic stability first.

 

Initiate strict bed rest and monitor vital signs (Option D): Strict bed rest is not appropriate in this scenario. Active intervention to stabilize the pelvis and manage shock is essential.

questions.text: Which of the following ligaments provide stability to the pelvis?

choices.text: Sacro-iliac ligament
Ilio-lumbar ligament
Superior pubic ligament
All of the above

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

 

Explanation:
Sacro-iliac ligament, Ilio-lumbar ligament, and Superior pubic ligament– all of these ligaments work together to reinforce the pelvic ring, enhance stability, and protect against injuries, particularly during movements or forces applied to the pelvis. Thus, all are essential for pelvic stability.

 

Pelvis Anatomy

  • Pelvic ring is a ring-shaped structure.
  • Front: joined by pubic symphysis.
  • Back: joined by sacro-iliac joints.
  • Features iliac wings, a common fracture site.
  • Continuity: pubic symphysis → pubic crest → pectineal line of pubis → arcuate line of ilium → ala and promontory of sacrum.
  • Anterior fractures may involve posterior injuries, causing instability.
  • Obturator nerve and sacral plexus cross the pelvic brim.
  • These nerves are at risk of injury during pelvic fractures.

Stability of the Pelvis

  • Stability depends on:
    • Posteriorly: sacro-iliac joints.
    • Anteriorly: symphysis pubis.
  • Sacro-iliac joints supported by strong sacro-iliac ligaments, ilio-lumbar, sacro-tuberous, and sacro-spinous ligaments.
  • Pubic symphysis reinforced by superior pubic ligament and the arcuate pubic ligament.

 

Mechanism of the Injury

  • Low energy injuries
    • Result from sudden muscular contractions in young athletes that cause an avulsion injury.
    • Low energy fall in an elderly with osteoporosis which may fracture the pelvic bones.
  • High energy injuries: Most common
    • RTA
    • Fall from heights.
    • Crush injuries

questions.text: A newborn presents with weakness in the left arm. On examination, the infant's hand shows a claw-like deformity like shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is most likely true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It involves injury to the C5-C6 nerve roots
The arm will present in a "waiter's tip" posture
It is more common than injuries affecting the upper brachial plexus
It is caused by damage to the C8-T1 nerve roots

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) It is caused by damage to the C8-T1 nerve roots

Explanation:
The clinical presentation described in the question is characteristic of Klumpke's Palsy, which involves injury to the C8-T1 nerve roots of the brachial plexus.

Erb's Palsy vs Klumpke's Palsy

Characteristic

Erb's Palsy

Klumpke's Palsy

Affected Nerve Roots

C5-C6 roots (Option A)

C8-T1 roots

Characteristic Posture

Waiter's tip posture (Option B)

Claw hand deformity

Arm Position
  • Internally rotated and adducted arm
  • Extended and pronated forearm
  • Flexed wrist
  • MCP joints extended
  • Interphalangeal joints are flexed

Frequency

Common (Option C)

Rare

questions.text: A 1-month-old infant presents with weakness in the right arm, inability to abduct the shoulder or flex the elbow, and the arm is held in internal rotation with the forearm pronated. An image of the infant is given below. Which of the following sequences best represents the appropriate management approach?

choices.text: MRI, observation for 6 months, surgical intervention if no improvement at 6 months
EMG, botulinum toxin injections, reassess at 1 year
X-ray, observation for 6 months, nerve graft surgery
MRI, early physiotherapy and hydrotherapy, reassess for surgical intervention if no improvement by 3-6 months

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) MRI, early physiotherapy and hydrotherapy, reassess for surgical intervention if no improvement by 3-6 months

Explanation:

In this scenario, the infant presents with weakness in the right arm, an inability to abduct the shoulder or flex the elbow, and the arm is held in internal rotation with the forearm pronated. These findings are characteristic of Erb's Palsy, which occurs due to an injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus, primarily affecting the C5 and C6 nerve roots.
 

After diagnosis of Erb’s Palsy, the management approach includes:

  1. Early immobilization followed by passive and active range of motion exercises
  2. Hydrotherapy: Provides an anti-gravity environment for strengthening muscles
  3. Physiotherapy: Includes gentle stretching, sensory stimulation, and strength exercises
  4. Occupational therapy: For long-term cases to help with daily activities
  5. Reassessment: If no improvement is seen by 3-6 months, surgical intervention may be considered
  6. Surgical options: Include nerve graft and nerve decompression if conservative management fails

Management of Erb’s Palsy

Diagnosis
  • Clinical diagnosis based on history and physical examination
  • MRI of brachial plexus and cervical cord (best imaging technique)
  • X-ray to exclude fractures
  • Electromyography (EMG) to assess muscle electrical activity
  • Nerve conduction studies (NCS) to measure nerve signal transmission
  • CT myelography for detailed imaging of spinal cord and nerve roots

Management
  • Conservative management done in most cases
  • Early immobilization followed by range of motion exercises
  • Hydrotherapy: Anti-gravity environment for muscle strengthening
  • Physiotherapy: Stretching, sensory stimulation, range of motion exercises
  • Occupational therapy: For long-term cases to assist with daily activities
  • Surgical intervention: Considered if no functional recovery with conservative management
    • Nerve graft
    • Nerve decompression
  • Medical therapy: Botulinum toxin injections for contracture relief

Prognosis
  • Generally favorable if treated early
  • About 90% of infants show recovery with time
  • 10% may continue to have a dysfunctional arm
  • Neglected cases may lead to 20-30% permanent deficit of nerve function

questions.text: A newborn presents with weakness in the right arm, inability to abduct the shoulder or flex the elbow, and the arm is held in internal rotation with the forearm pronated. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this condition?

choices.text: Injury to the lower trunk of the brachial plexus (C8-T1)
Compression of the median nerve at the carpal tunnel
Injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus (C5-C6)
Avulsion of the cervical nerve roots from the spinal cord

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus (C5-C6)

Explanation:
The clinical presentation described is characteristic of Erb's Palsy, which is caused by an injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus, specifically involving the C5 and C6 nerve roots.

Erb’s Palsy - Pathophysiology and Clinical Features

Aspect

Details

Pathophysiology
  • Injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus (C5-C6)
  • Most commonly caused by traction of the neck during delivery
  • Severity ranges from neuropraxia (least severe) to neurotmesis (most severe)
  • Can involve C7 in more severe cases (Extended Erb's Palsy)

Clinical Features
  • Weakness of the arm
  • Loss of sensation in the arm
  • Paralysis and atrophy of deltoid, biceps, and brachialis muscles
  • Limited shoulder abduction- Deltoid, Supraspinatus
  • Inability to flex the elbow- Biceps brachii, Brachialis
  • Internal rotation and pronation of the arm- Subscapularis, Pronator teres, Pectoralis major.
  • "Waiter's tip" posture
  • Absent Moro reflex on the affected side
  • Present grasp reflex

Injury to the lower trunk (C8-T1) causes Klumpke's palsy, which primarily affects the hand and presents with a "claw hand" appearance. (Option A)

Compression of the median nerve at the carpal tunnel would not cause the shoulder and elbow symptoms described in Erb's Palsy. (Option B)

While avulsion of cervical nerve roots can occur in severe brachial plexus injuries, it's not the typical pathophysiology of Erb's palsy and would likely result in more extensive deficits. (Option D)

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with an elevated left scapula that is noticeably higher than the right, a shorter neck appearance as shown in the image below, and painless shoulder movements, although there is some limitation in abduction. The mother reports that this condition was apparent at birth. Which of the following conditions is most likely the diagnosis?

choices.text: Klippel–Feil syndrome
Madelung's deformity
Cleidocranial dysostosis
Sprengel's deformity

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Sprengel's deformity

 

Explanation:

Sprengel's Deformity involves the failure of the scapula to descend properly, resulting in an elevated scapula, noticeable at birth. The features of painless shoulder movements with some limitation in abduction align perfectly with the described condition.

 

Sprengel’s Deformity

  • A congenital condition where the scapula fails to descend properly during embryonic development.
    • Imperfect descent of the shoulder girdle by the third month of pregnancy
    • Possible presence of a fibrous band between the skull and scapula
  • Elevated scapula (2–10 cm higher than normal)
  • Hypoplastic and abnormally shaped scapula
  • Neck may appear shorter; potential for kyphosis or scoliosis
  • Deformity noticeable at birth
  • Shoulder movements are painless, but abduction and elevation may be limited
  • Torticollis present in ~10% of cases
  • Associated congenital anomalies (e.g., cervical rib, spina bifida)
  • Potential absence or alterations in the trapezius and other shoulder muscles
  • Treatment:
    • Mild cases require no treatment
    • Severe cases may necessitate surgery after age three, involving muscle release or trapezius muscle origin transfer

Klippel–Feil Syndrome (Option A)

  • A widespread disorder characterized by abnormalities in the cervical spine and occipital bones.
  • Congenital short and stiff neck due to fused or deformed cervical vertebrae.
  • Key Features:
    • Bilateral failure of scapular descent.
    • Appearance of having no neck.
    • Low hairline and bilateral neck webbing.
    • Significant limitation of neck movement.

Madelung's Deformity (Option B):

  • This deformity affects the distal radial epiphysis, leading to a deformity of the radius and dislocation of the ulna.
  • It is unrelated to scapular positioning or shoulder movement and therefore is not applicable to the scenario.

Fig. Comparison of Madelung’s deformity with normal anatomy
 

Fig. Madelung’s deformity on physical examination and radiograph

 

Cleidocranial Dysostosis (Option C):

  • An autosomal dominant disorder characterized by hypoplasia or absence of the clavicles and flat bones.
  • Patients typically have drooping shoulders and a narrow chest.
  • While it does involve skeletal abnormalities, it does not fit the presentation of an elevated scapula or shoulder movement limitations.

Fig. Cleidocranial Dysostosis

questions.text: Regarding fracture healing, which of the following statements is INCORRECT?

choices.text: Children's fractures heal faster than adults
Spiral fractures unite more slowly than oblique fractures
Cancellous bones unite faster than cortical bones
Open fractures are prone to delayed union

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Spiral fractures unite more slowly than oblique fractures

Explanation:
Spiral fractures unite faster than oblique fractures, not more slowly.

Factors Affecting Fracture Healing:

Faster Healing

Slower Healing

Age: Fractures unite faster in children than in adults (Option A)

Fracture Type: Open fractures and comminuted fractures often go into delayed union and non-union (Option D)

Bone Type: Flat cancellous bones unite faster than tubular cortical bones (Option C)

Bone Diseases: Osteoporosis and bone infection delay fracture healing

Fracture Pattern: Spiral fractures unite faster than oblique fractures, which unite faster than transverse fractures

Nutrition: Poor nutrition can hinder fracture healing

Reduction: Good apposition of fracture results in faster union

Poor circulation

questions.text: Regarding the Ilizarov technique for distraction osteogenesis, which of the following statements is INCORRECT?

choices.text: The technique involves the use of a ring fixator that stabilizes the limb and allows for controlled distraction or compression.
Distraction osteogenesis requires a dynamic state where the site of osteogenesis undergoes either controlled distraction or controlled compression.
The rate of distraction or compression is typically carried out at 1 mm per day, done in four sittings of 0.25 mm each.
The Ilizarov technique is ineffective in correcting deformities or treating non-unions.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) The Ilizarov technique is ineffective in correcting deformities or treating non-unions.

Explanation:
The Ilizarov technique is versatile and can be used for multiple purposes such as correcting deformities, not just limb lengthening.

Key points on Ilizarov technique:

  • The Ilizarov technique is mainly used for management of difficult non-unions and limb lengthening.
  • It's based on the principle that osteogenesis requires a dynamic state, achieved through controlled distraction or compression. (Option B)
  • Intramembranous Ossification: This is the primary method of bone formation during distraction osteogenesis. Osteoblasts directly form bone without an intermediate cartilage stage (unlike endochondral ossification, seen in long bone growth).
  • The technique uses a ring fixator that stabilizes the limb while allowing controlled movement of bone fragments. (Option A)
  • Distraction or compression is typically done at a rate of 1 mm per day, in four 0.25 mm increments. (Option C)
  • First corticotomy is done to expose the metaphyseal bone. Then 10 days are given for a latent period for hematoma formation.

The technique is effective for:

  • Limb lengthening, especially when shortening is associated with deformity.
  • Non-union treatment, particularly those resistant to conventional methods.
  • Correction of deformities, which can be done simultaneously with lengthening.

questions.text: Identify the correct sequence of the mentioned stages of fracture healing

choices.text: Inflammation, Callus formation, Remodeling, Hematoma formation, Modeling
Hematoma formation, Inflammation, Callus formation, Remodeling, Modeling
Hematoma formation, Inflammation, Modeling, Remodeling, Callus formation
Callus formation, Hematoma formation, Inflammation, Modeling, Remodeling

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hematoma formation, Inflammation, Callus formation, Remodeling, Modeling

 

Explanation:

STAGES IN FRACTURE HEALING OF CORTICAL BONE:

 

Stage of hematoma
  • The initial stage lasts up to 7 days.
  • Blood leaks from torn vessels and forms a hematoma around the fracture.
  • The periosteum and soft tissues are stripped away from the fracture ends.
  • Fracture ends suffer from ischemic necrosis over a few millimeters.
  • Some osteocytes die, while others become active and help in healing.

Stage of granulation tissue
  • The granulation tissue stage lasts 2-3 weeks.
  • Precursor cells produce blood vessels, fibroblasts, and osteoblasts.
  • Soft granulation tissue forms between fracture fragments.
  • It provides support without structural rigidity.
  • A fibrous mesh from the blood clot supports fibroblast and capillary growth.
  • Macrophages and giant cells remove the blood clot.
  • In bone healing, granulation tissue differentiates into osteoblasts to form new bone.

Stage of callus
  • This stage lasts 4-12 weeks, during which granulation tissue differentiates into osteoblasts.
  • These cells create an intercellular matrix that becomes impregnated with calcium salts, forming the callus, or woven bone.
  • This callus, visible on X-rays about 3 weeks post-fracture, provides initial strength and indicates union.

Stage of remodeling

  • Formerly known as the consolidation stage.
  • Woven bone is replaced by mature lamellar bone.
  • This occurs in multicellular units, with callus replaced by lamellar bone.
  • The process is slow, taking 1 to 4 years.

Stage of modeling

  • Formerly known as the remodeling stage.
  • Bone is gradually strengthened.
  • Cortices sharpen at the endosteal and periosteal surfaces.
  • Local bone strains from weight-bearing stresses and muscle forces stimulate this process.
  • More noticeable in children with angulated fractures.
  • Limited remodeling occurs in adult fractures.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the differences between primary and secondary fracture healing?

choices.text: Primary healing involves the formation of a fibrous callus, while secondary healing bypasses the callus stage with direct lamellar bone formation.
Primary healing occurs with absolute stability and direct bone remodeling, while secondary healing is a process involving callus formation and occurs with relative stability.
Primary healing is faster due to the lack of callus formation, while secondary healing is delayed due to endochondral ossification.
Primary healing occurs with undisturbed fracture hematoma, while secondary healing occurs when the hematoma is surgically removed.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Primary healing occurs with absolute stability and direct bone remodeling, while secondary healing is a process involving callus formation and occurs with relative stability.

Explanation:
Primary healing requires absolute stability (surgical fixation) and healing occurs without a callus. Secondary healing occurs with relative stability (e.g., casting) and involves callus formation.

Feature

Primary (Direct) Healing

Secondary (Indirect) Healing

Process

Direct bone healing without callus formation. (Option A)

Involves the classical stages of healing: hematoma, callus formation, and remodeling.

Mechanism

Lamellar bone forms directly across the fracture line by direct extension of osteons.

Healing occurs through endochondral and intramembranous ossification with callus formation.

Fracture Hematoma

Occurs when the fracture hematoma is disturbed, usually in surgically treated fractures. (Option D)

Occurs when the fracture hematoma remains undisturbed, typical of non-operative treatment.

Callus Formation

No callus formation; difficult to evaluate on X-rays due to direct healing.

Callus formation is visible on X-rays and bridges the fracture site.

Stability Requirement

Requires absolute stability with rigid internal fixation (e.g., surgical plates).

Requires relative stability, often managed with casting or external fixation.

Healing Speed

Slower healing due to the direct remodeling of bone. (Option C)

Faster healing, as callus provides early mechanical strength.

Mechanical Continuity

Mechanical continuity is reestablished without callus formation.

Strength is restored by the callus, which provides initial stability.

Bone Contact

Direct contact between bone cortices (anatomical reduction).

Gaps between bone fragments are bridged by callus formation.

Clinical Use

Used in surgically treated fractures requiring perfect alignment.

Common in non-surgically treated fractures (e.g., casting, external fixation).

X-ray Evaluation

Hard to evaluate healing on X-rays due to lack of callus formation.

Callus formation makes healing progress visible on X-rays.

questions.text: A 13-year-old obese boy presents with a limp and pain in his left hip and knee that has been gradually worsening over the past month. On examination, his left leg is externally rotated and appears shorter. The hip has limited internal rotation and abduction. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease
Septic arthritis of the hip
Slipped capital femoral epiphysis
Developmental dysplasia of the hip

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Slipped capital femoral epiphysis

Explanation:
The patient's presentation aligns with slipped capital femoral epiphysis based on the clinical features.

  • SCFE occurs when the femoral head becomes displaced due to slippage at the growth plate, often linked to factors such as mechanical stress and hormonal influences during periods of rapid growth.
  • This displacement leads to altered hip mechanics and can cause pain, limited mobility, and long-term joint complications if not addressed.

SCFE presents with the following characteristics:

  1. Age: 13 years old, which falls within the typical age range for SCFE (12-14 years)
  2. Gender: Male, which is more common in SCFE
  3. Body habitus: Obese, a known risk factor for SCFE
  4. Symptoms: Gradual onset of hip and knee pain with a limp
  5. Physical examination: External rotation of the affected leg, limited hip internal rotation, and abduction
  6. Associated with Hypothyroidism and Hypogonadism.

Fig. Plain X-ray of Slipped capital femoral epiphysis

 

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE)

Definition

Displacement of the upper femoral epiphysis at the growth plate, usually postero-medially, resulting in coxa vara

Age & Gender
  • Occurs at puberty (between 12-14 years)
  • More common in boys

Risk Factors
  • Obesity
  • Endocrine abnormalities
  • Short and obese children

Clinical Features
  • Pain in the groin, often radiating to the thigh and knee
  • Limp
  • External rotation of the affected leg, Shortening of the limb.
  • Limitation of hip movements, especially abduction and internal rotation
  • Positive Trendelenburg's sign
  • Drehmann's Sign is characterized by external rotation and abduction of the hip when the knee is flexed, indicating instability or weakness in the hip joint

Radiological Features
  • Best seen on the X-ray: lateral view of the hip
  • AP view: Growth plate displaced towards metaphyseal side
  • Lateral view: Head is angulated on the neck
  • Klein's Line: This is an imaging line drawn on an X-ray of the hip, where a line is drawn along the superior aspect of the femoral neck. The line should intersect the capital femoral epiphysis. If the epiphysis is above this line, it indicates a potential displacement or abnormality in the femoral head.
  • Trethowan Sign: This sign is observed on an X-ray when there is a widening of the medial joint space of the hip, indicating a possible displacement of the femoral head. It may also suggest a higher likelihood of osteonecrosis in the affected hip.

Treatment
  • Acute slip: Closed reduction and pinning
  • Gradual slip: Depends on severity; in situ fixation or corrective osteotomy
  • Prophylactic pinning of unaffected side in unilateral cases

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease typically affects younger children (4-10 years) and typically presents with limping, hip or knee pain, reduced hip mobility, and possible leg length discrepancy in children aged 4-10 years. In Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease, decreased movements typically include hip abduction, internal rotation, external rotation, and flexion. (Option A)

Septic arthritis of the hip usually has an acute onset with fever and severe pain, which is not described in this case. (Option B)

Developmental dysplasia of the hip is typically diagnosed in infancy or early childhood, not in adolescence. (Option D)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is admitted to the orthopedic ward with a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. The orthopedic surgeon decides to apply traction as part of the treatment plan. Which of the following traction methods would be most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Skin traction with adhesive plaster
Skeletal traction with Steinmann pin
Russell's traction
Bryant's traction

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B)Skeletal traction with Steinmann pin

Explanation:
Skeletal traction with Steinmann pin is the most appropriate traction method for treating a supracondylar fracture of the humerus in an adult patient.

Skin and Skeletal Traction

Characteristic

Skin Traction

Skeletal Traction

Required force

Mild to moderate force

Moderate to severe force

Age used for

Children

Adults

Applied with

Adhesive plaster

Steinmann pin, K-wire

Applied on

On skin

Through bone

Weight permitted

Up to 3-4 kg

Up to 20 kg

Used for

Short duration

Long duration

Image

Skin traction with adhesive plaster is typically used for children and can only apply mild to moderate force, which may be insufficient for this fracture. (Option A)

Russell's traction is used for trochanteric fractures in adults, not for supracondylar fracture of the humerus. (Option C)

Bryant's traction is specifically used for fracture shaft of femur in children aged 2-6 years. (Option D)

questions.text: A 42-year-old software developer presents with pain and tenderness on the outer aspect of her right elbow. The pain worsens when she extends her wrist against resistance. She denies any recent injury but mentions spending long hours typing and using a mouse. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Golfer’s elbow
Student’s elbow
Tennis elbow
Cubital tunnel syndrome

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C)Tennis elbow

Explanation:
In this case, the patient's presentation aligns with Tennis elbow:

  1. Pain and tenderness on the outer aspect of the elbow (lateral epicondyle)
  2. Pain worsens with wrist extension against resistance
  3. History of repetitive activities (long hours of typing and using a mouse)

Lateral epicondylitis (Tennis elbow)

Definition

A condition characterized by pain and tenderness at the lateral epicondyle of the humerus due to non-specific inflammation at the origin of the extensor muscles of the forearm

Causes
  • Overuse of extensor muscles
  • Repetitive activities (e.g., tennis, typing, using mouse)
  • Non-specific inflammation at muscle origin

Clinical Features
  • Pain and tenderness precisely localized to the lateral epicondyle of the humerus
  • Pain aggravated by extending the wrist against resistance
  • Normal X-ray findings

Tests
  • Cozen's test: Also known as the resisted wrist extension test or resistive tennis elbow test, this test involves the patient making a fist and resisting wrist extension while the examiner applies pressure. The test is positive if the patient experiences pain on the lateral epicondyle.
  • Maudsley's test: This test involves the patient pronating their forearm and resisting extension of the third digit of their hand while the examiner stabilizes the humerus. The test is positive if the patient experiences sudden pain on the lateral epicondyle.
  • Mills's test: Another common test for tennis elbow.

Treatment
  • Initial: Analgesics, anti-inflammatory drugs
  • If no response: Local injection of hydrocortisone at the point of maximum tenderness
  • Physical therapy and activity modification

Golfer's elbow (Medial epicondylitis) affects the inner aspect of the elbow, not the outer aspect. (Option A)

Student elbow (Olecranon bursitis) causes swelling and pain at the tip of the elbow, not the lateral aspect. (Option B)

Cubital tunnel syndrome affects the ulnar nerve at the elbow, causing numbness and tingling in the ring and little fingers, not pain on the lateral aspect of the elbow. (Option D)

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of alcohol abuse presents to the clinic with difficulty straightening his right hand as shown in the image below. He mentions that this has progressively worsened over the past year. Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition he may be experiencing?

choices.text: The flexion deformity primarily affects the distal interphalangeal joints of the fingers.
Thickening of the palmar aponeurosis is a key feature of this condition.
Individuals with liver cirrhosis have a higher incidence of this condition.
Observation is often sufficient for mild cases of this condition.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) The flexion deformity primarily affects the distal interphalangeal joints of the fingers.

Explanation:
In this case, the patient's presentation aligns with Dupuytren's contracture:

  1. Progressive deformity of the hand.
  2. Difficulty fully extending the ring and little fingers.
  3. Thickening of the palmar fascia.
  4. Flexion contracture of the affected fingers.
  5. History of alcohol abuse (which may be associated with liver cirrhosis, a risk factor for Dupuytren's)
  6. In conditions like Dupuytren's contracture, the primary flexion deformity affects the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints, while the DIP joints are often less involved or may remain straight.
  7. The characteristic presentation involves the MCP and PIP joints being flexed, with the DIP joints typically being unaffected or less affected.

Dupuytren's contracture

 

Definition

A condition characterized by a flexion deformity of one or more fingers due to thickening and shortening of the palmar aponeurosis

Pathoanatomy
  • Thickening of the palmar aponeurosis (Option B)
  • Involvement of fibrous flexor sheaths and lateral digital sheet
  • Progressive contracture leading to finger flexion

Clinical Features
  • Early stages: Thickening at bases of ring and little fingers
  • Later stages: Flexion deformity of fingers
  • Primarily affects ring finger, then little finger
  • MP and PIP joints are flexed, DIP joints often not affected

Risk Factors
  • Increased incidence in cirrhotic patients (alcohol abuse) (Option C)
  • Association with epileptics on sodium hydantoin
  • Possible genetic predisposition

Treatment
  • Mild cases: Observation (Option D)
  • Severe cases: Surgical excision of the palmar aponeurosis

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with numbness and tingling in her thumb, index, and middle fingers. Symptoms worsen at night and improve during the day. She also reports hand and wrist pain, along with weakness in her grip. Which of the following clinical signs is consistent with her condition?

choices.text: Thumb opposition and abduction is spared.
Sensory loss affecting the entire hand.
Atrophy of the thenar eminence.
Pain and paresthesias arise during wrist extension.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Atrophy of the thenar eminence

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms of tingling and numbness in the thumb, index, and middle fingers, worsening at night are classic signs of carpal tunnel syndrome.
  • Atrophy of the thenar eminence indicates significant nerve dysfunction and is commonly seen in advanced cases of carpal tunnel syndrome.

Carpal tunnel syndrome

Definition

Compression of the median nerve as it passes through the carpal tunnel in the wrist

Symptoms
  • Numbness, tingling in thumb, index, and middle fingers
  • Pain in hand and wrist
  • Weakness in grip
  • Symptoms often worse at night and improve during the day.
  • Advanced cases may lead to constant symptoms, hand weakness, clumsiness, and muscle atrophy.

Structures Affected
  • Median Nerve: Compressed within the carpal tunnel, leading to symptoms and signs.
  • Flexor Tendons: The nine flexor tendons passing through the carpal tunnel can become inflamed, further compressing the median nerve.

Structures Spared
  • Thenar Eminence: Sensory loss generally spares this area because its nerve (palmar sensory cutaneous nerve) bypasses the carpal tunnel.

Clinical Signs
  • Weakness: Notable weakness in thumb abduction and opposition. (Option A)
  • Atrophy: Possible atrophy of the thenar eminence in advanced cases.
  • Sensory Loss: Loss typically affects the median nerve distribution (thumb, index, middle, and radial half of the fourth digit). (Option B)

Causes
  • Idiopathic- commonest cause
  • Inflammatory causes- Rheumatoid arthritis, wrist osteoarthritis
  • Post-traumatic causes- Bone thickening after a Colles' fracture
  • Endocrine causes- Myxoedema, Acromegaly

Diagnostic Tests
  • Nerve Conduction Studies (NCS) - primary diagnostic test
  • Electromyography (EMG)
  • Carpal Compression Test: Positive if pain/paresthesias occur during pressure application over the carpal tunnel.
  • Phalen Test: Positive if pain/paresthesias arise during wrist flexion. (Option D)
  • Tinel Test: Positive if tapping over the carpal tunnel elicits symptoms.

Treatment
  • Conservative: Wrist splinting, NSAIDs, activity modification
  • Corticosteroid injections
  • Surgical: Carpal tunnel release (for severe or refractory cases)
